newsitem.title: USA: Hercules muscles into growing corp debt arena.
newsitem.headline: Hercules muscles into growing corp debt arena.

text.p: Hercules Inc is expected to muscle in among other opportunistic issuers looking to capitalize on lower rates to finance debt, as anxious investors clamor for more, dealers said.
"Market tone remains very good and supply has been easily absorbed," said one syndicate source. "I imagine we'll have another busy week."
Currently, the yield on the benchmark 30-year U.S. Treasury bond remains below 6.50 percent, drawing more issuers into the market.
Among them is Hercules' $200 million debt offering.
Salomon Brothers is expected to underwrite the deal.
Quebecor Printing, a unit of Quebecor Inc, is a leading commercial printer in Canada and Europe and the second largest in the United States.
Another issuer, Taubman Realty, is expected to issue $100 million in debt via Merrill Lynch.
IES Industries is expected to bring a $135 million 12-year issue via competitive bid on Wednesday, players said.
Still on the investment grade horizon is a $2.5 billion debt offering by Raytheon Co expected next week.
A big week is on tap for the high-yield market as about 20 new junk issues totalling $3.5 billion are expected to hit the market, dealers said.
Close to $700 million in domestic 144a private placement debt deals are slated to come to market on Monday, with another $350 million coming via the euro 144a market, players said.
Among the deals is Primus Telecommunications Group's $125 million seven-year notes via Lehman Brothers. Price talk on the issue is seen between 11.50 to 11.75 percent, syndicates sources said.
Golden Ocean Group Ltd is also set to tap the market with $150 million in seven-year 144a notes, players said.

So far on Monday, among foreign issuers, Mexico based Axa SA de CV, a diversified manufacturer of industrial products and processed meats, sold $200 million seven-year euro 144a debt at 300 basis points via Chase Securities.
Guatemala is also expected to tap the euro market with a $150 million 10-year 144a debt offering, sources said.
Jakarta-based Tjiwi Kimia Finance Mauritus Ltd, the Indonesian paper firm, is slated to bring $400 million seven-year senior unsecured 144a notes via Goldman Sachs & Co.
Price talk on the issue is seen at 400 basis points over Treasuries, sources said.

Meanwhile, last week saw about $8.4 billion in new straight corporate debt issuance hit the market amid falling interest rates, dealers said. About $5.0 billion in high-grade debt was priced, with another $3.4 billion in junk offerings.
The steady pace of debt issuance is expected to continue; however, players will be watching this week's batch of U.S. economic statistics for any change in market tone.
"We started out last week not expecting a whole lot but we came off with a very good week for issuance," said one syndicate source.
"This week we have a lot of economic numbers so we're just waiting to see what develops," he added.
Although no economic data is scheduled for Monday, Tuesday's reports will include U.S. employment cost index for the second quarter and July U.S. consumer confidence.
(( -- Nancy Leinfuss, 212-859-1675 ))
